topic.title: Why I Use Git Center
topic.body:
A comment by merithtk on another thread made me think about why I host most of my projects solely on Git Center, something I will probably write a more in-depth defense of on my blog when I find the time.

[Git Center](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/) is missing a lot of features that Gitlab and Github have to offer. I even maintain projects on Gitlab every day and many of the projects that I use are only available on Github, and yet I don't really miss any of the extra features they have to offer.

One of the reasons for that is that my projects on ZeroNet are solo projects. Either I started them and barely anyone ever contributes to them, or I took them over from someone else. If I had to work full-time with a team on a project I'd be unlikely to use Git Center. But that said even for teamwork I don't use a lot of the workflow features Gitlab has to offer because other (non-integrated) services just do them that much better. I won't get into the details here, but the takeaway is that this is really not a big deal.
If checking out and pushing to a repo was as easy as `git clone zero://1ZER0NETAddRESS` instead of `path_to_zeronet_folder/data/1ZER0NETAddRESS`, and if using those repos was as easy as `pm_of_your_choice install zero://AddRESS`, I don't think I'd find much hinder to my workflow **at all**, even when working with a team.

What makes me stick to Git Center is the knowledge that *if I die tomorrow my projects will be there until no one cares about them anymore*, (even if that is tomorrow).

- Self-hosting would stop when my computer is turned of.
- My droplet will dry out together with the credits I've topped up.
- And with centralized services it all depends on the whims of the corporation and the people influencing them (governments, big money, media, activists).

I don't know what the future of the internet looks like, but we *will* see repositories disappear one way or another. And with that in mind I'd rather trust a bunch of Guy Fawkes mask wearing randos with my pet projects than Bill Gates and Xi Jing Ping.

topic.title: Looking for Open Source Hardware vendors
topic.body:
I've got a stack of Raspberry Pi's and they're great, but I'm looking to buy/build a home server that's a little more powerful.

Specifications:
- Processor with more than 4 cores, but I can live with 4 if more isn't available.
- Processor speed isn't as important, I will be using it to test multi-threaded applications.
- Has/supports at least 16GB RAM
- Supports internal (i.e. SATA) hard drives and RAID
- Multiple ethernet ports is a plus.
- Don't care about graphics, audio, wireless, etc. support, it's a server.
- **100% Open Source Hardware** is important to me :-)

Any suggestions are appreciated, I don't care whether it's RISC-V, ARM, x86 or any other architecture, as long as [Rust can compile to it](https://forge.rust-lang.org/release/platform-support.html)

> [aspidochelone](#comment_15_1PPUrYcZ1E1rGkkE6PH18Qi43LRsKABo1Z): What's the blocklist, who controls it, and how long is it going to take for a court to order them to block everybody?

- Blocklists are made by individuals and aren't capable of banning any person, zite or content from the network. As the network and it's users grows we'll likely be seeing community run blocklists.
- Users themselves choose which blocklists they enable
- Users can choose to overwrite decisions made by the blocklist if they wish “Yes I know this site is blocked, download it anyway" and there is no way to enforce them on the network. People could refuse to update to the clients that enforce them, or just start their own fork of ZN.
- Users can remove a blocklist if they disagree with the decisions made by the owner(s) in who to block/unblock. This means there will be competition between blocklist owners, hopefully leading to quality blocklists.

> [trevorlaneray](#comment_11_12eXcQ1ojAbyCoCcMQ3JAKi73wgcJrjow3): Ehh, I'm not a boomer, but I am pretty new to this.I went ahead and enabled "Tor: Always" almost immediately after starting.Am I doing it right? >.<

Using Tor is probably your best option. I'm not using Tor Always mode, but I tend to stick to ZeroTalk, ZeroMe and people's blogs and I'm not too worried about doxxing. If you're hosting a zite that could make you a target for internet vigilantes it's probably best to enforce Tor and maybe disallow 3rd party scripts (or use TBB, though you'll have the white image bug on some zites like ZeroMe). 
People have said for a long time that Tor Always should be default behavior, and I agree. It's one of the things that makes ZeroNet difficult for tech-illiterate people and could result in poor trust.

> [chinchin](#comment_12_18HYVwCAgri1SgiYZcEZMehKoXZo6Eg7im): Does using Tor Always also make using a normal browser with Zeronet anonymous or does it only work with the TBB?

Tor Always anonymizes all connections made by ZeroNet, there's a couple of deanonymization techniques that could still be used:
1. A malicious zite could have javascript in it that makes a clearnet connection, leaking your IP. On top of that it could also send information about what ID you're using. (ie. just like on the normal internet, don't blindly trust websites).
2. A zite could include an image with `src="clearnet address"`, that address could be harvesting IP's.
3. Clicking on a clearnet link could lead to a page that collects IPs.

Note: Some zites use clearnet connections for valid purposes though: ZeroID makes a clearnet connection when you make a new ID to prevent spam (though you can use TBB no problem)

> [nickwa](#comment_274_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehEEKKJj): What's TBB?

It's the Tor Browser Bundle.

> [bigbadbob](#comment_116_1CLhLYdMKjXtium9yjuRkSnFvPfdoUTXAj): im probably the most technically retarded person on the face of the planet.everything seems fine.    on debian so i gotta type "sudo python3 zeronet.py"i got green lights with no warnings.

I hope you're joking. Sudo is not required for ZN at all. If it isn't working without sudo, try chown-ing your zeronet folder recursively to your user. Maybe you copied some lingering file permission settings from your old installation.

> [bigbadbob](#comment_119_1CLhLYdMKjXtium9yjuRkSnFvPfdoUTXAj): cool...  im learning.   im gonna have to dive in deeper.   Ive got recent version of zeronet.     i was reading something about backing up the folder or just the file.   I figured to whole folder made sence.
Some people like to backup their whole data folder to have a kind of snapshot of what ZeroNet looked like at that moment of time. But usually you'll be fine backing up your users.json file. This will allow you to restore your ID's, as well as the keys to owned zites. I recommend keeping it somewhere safe. It's also best to put ZeroNet on an encrypted harddrive, that way someone with physical access to your device can't steal your keys (as long as you don't leave it unlocked)
BTL sounds like it could be BitTorrent related. Never had module like that missing on Ubuntu or Debian though.

1565358798_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc3.body:
I've only read about 50% of this thread, and unfortunately don't have enough time to go through the rest, but I'll throw my two cents into the conversation.

> If nofish dies, ZeroNet dies.

False. 1. Nofish isn't the only dev who contributes to ZN. 2. Even if development stops, ZN will still function. 3. There's some devs here on ZN who would be willing to put in some time working on it if necessary (myself included).

> ZeroTalk limit of 50Kb. Nofish is the only person who can increase that.

Yup, it's a thing. You may not like, I for sure don't. But it's there for a good reason, it prevents ids from spamming too much.
Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe nofish has automated the limit increasing. I believe it's a script that he's running that automatically increases the limits for people when they reach close to their limit if they're not spamming. I've heard from some people that their limit was increased without ever bothering him. (And as a dev I think it'd be a waste of time not to automate such a thing.)

> ZeroNet is centralized.

ZeroNet isn't. ZeroNet allows you to build centralized things on top of it. That's what ZeroID and others like it are. KaffieID is decentralized IIRC, and it would be nice if more zites allowed you to use it, but it's also confusing because it allows username overlap.
The problem of trackers being a bottleneck and weak point of the network is a really good one. It's something that could be solved, but it just hasn't yet. This is mostly because it hasn't been necessary so far.

1568607154_16BaY5JLzzA8TPe4jzXtp3CfZi3Qk.body:
If you'd like to limit bandwidth, you could wrap your program into something like trickle (`sudo apt install trickle`, then `trickle -u [upload bandwidth] -d [download bandwidth] [application]`). You can use this to limit your weekly maximum as well, just realize that this means you'll be limiting the speed at which other nodes can download from yours. If you're going this route and you're not expecting your node to upload at max bandwidth 24/7, I'd recommend setting the limit in trickle a bit higher so your fellow ZeroNetters can enjoy a better user experience.

*BEWARE:* I haven't tested whether this also works when using ZeroNet over Tor.

1570935984_149NKX715zpvjyRaoR7ZdVKMDQ9BQ.body:
Let's take a step back and try to find out what went wrong. For this I'll be making the following assumptions:

1) She was armed, likely thinking the people outside her house were burglars. A reasonable response to flashlights in your backyard I'd say. This seems likely to me because a gun was found close to her body according to several of the reports.

2) The neighbor had mentioned an open door in his call to the police and also that he had not heard shouting or other signs of a struggle. The officers who were dispatched did not receive their information directly from the neighbor, but from an intermediary deskplant. The information they received indicated a possible break-in had occurred and that (potentially armed) burglars were still inside.

These two need to be taken into consideration before jumping on the "police evil" or "police hate black people" bandwagon. If there is so far no indication of evil, nor racism, what are we looking at?

# Incompetence.

It's very well possible that the first part of the problem occurred when the situation was miscommunicated to the officers on duty: the neighbor called about an open door in the context of neglect (a ridiculous state of affairs when neighbors do such a thing, but let's not dwell on that). Somewhere along the way however, as in a game of Chinese whispers, the police may have arrived at the scene with a completely different idea of the situation at hand. From there on things only got worse for the victim. I have no proof for this, but I imagine the first thing she did when she noticed people were lurking around the house was pick up her gun and try to get a better look at what was going on, possibly with her gun drawn. The police officers at her house were clearly not well-trained and not fit to do their duty - an occurrence far too common in the USA. They should obviously have ID'd themselves and given the victim more time to process their orders before even thinking of shooting! That however does not say anything about their character as human beings, that speaks of an institutional problem, and no, not a racist one, at least not with the evidence in this case so far.

This is truly a sad story. In my mind however, what we should take from this (at least with the evidence that has been released so far) is that we need to **set the bar higher for police**, not only on the street, **but also off**: as I stated before, even though the officer who shot was at fault **legally**, it's very well possible that the person(s) sitting behind a desk who sent them out there with misleading information is just as much to blame as him (if that is indeed what happened).

Of course this take on the story does not make for good headlines, so the media will steer clear of it.

As always: Feel free to point out if there is evidence I've missed in this assessment, or if you think my reasoning is erroneous.

1571689463_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac.body:
i2p is mostly like the traditional internet with an anonymization layer on top in the vein of Tor, but better, particularly for bittorrent-style application (like ZeroNet), in itself it's not particularly interesting to me, but I do run RetroShare over it.

IPFS is good for static content, again not so interesting in itself, but good to be used together with other things. Websites can use ipfsjs to serve static content through it.

RetroShare is good for private content, it has p2p e-mail, forums, etc. but not able to do public things. I use it with friends and family instead of normal emails and chat. Could really do with a better interface. Excited about the whole Tsunami Democratic thing in Catalonia, looks like this may help RetroShare rise to fame. If they could now host their website on ZeroNet as well to prevent it from being censored as happened during the Catalonian votes, that would really be awesome.

None of these are in competition with each other. Tor and I2P kind of are. As are RetroShare and GnuNet. ZeroNet could be seen as a competitor of Freenet, but they're really different in concept so I'd say it's a bad comparison.

1571981535_14g2gXnsZdEPShFJkGdh5W3eGXmKz.body:
> What would the legal ramifications be? You did not willingly download said content,
If you were to come across cp on any clearnet website, your computer could have a cached copy of that file. From a technical perspective this would be very similar: unwitting download of illegal content. I don't know anything about law, but I doubt this is going to be the issue.

> you are not willingly distributing said content.
And that's where we get into interesting territory. The owner of a server is only liable if they don't remove the content within x hours of it being reported to them (this depends on the country), in Germany I believe this is now 1 or 2 hours (which is ridiculous, this means being asleep while a criminal posts to your clearnet forum could land you in prison).

Does the same apply to peers in a decentralized web? There's no legal precedent yet AFAIK.

> the procurement of an expert witness the court is inclined to listen to who can testify on your behalf would be essential
This. Courts don't understand technology, and there's no chance in hell that's going to be any different with revolutionary technology such as ZN.

1578001269_12BRJSQrTETJVZzt2jHdqPywv3Sdu.body:
Corrupted downloads should not be a problem, ZeroNet verifies the hashes of file(part)s it receives from peers. So both inbound and outbound data will be trashed and redownloaded until the verification succeeds.

Having trouble publishing could lead to problems though, I'm not sure myself whether ZeroNet will try automatically republish later or you will have to do so manually (e.g. editing a post and saving it again). Avoid using the same user on multiple devices if you're having trouble (you may overwrite unpublished data otherwise)

> [hferbwauif](#comment_34_16dnrZKRMLhQCjv6nxx7tP5KJ2H2PdqRxP): One thing is theory and another one is practice. If the blocks always get corrupted before they have been completed you'll never finish downloading anything...

That's not what was asked. The question was specifically about whether it would lead to corrupt files. But you are indeed correct: if all the parts you receive/send are corrupted in transit you will not be able to download/seed anything.

I have used ZeroNet over connections as slow as 10-20kb/s without problem. And I've also used it in places with unstable wifi availability and the most trouble I've had is that publishing would fail because the wifi cut out. It'd be interesting to hear from people who've used it over even slower connections though.

1578225013_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8.body:
> [gitcenter](#comment_1184_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Unfortunately, not any time soon. Sorry for that, I switched to the main ZeroNet fork because I thought it's more important for now, until we get more users and such.

What was the reasoning for a ZN fork?

I'm making my own (Py3-compatible) Rust implementation of ZN and I'd like to take features people want to see into account while developing.

> [filips](#comment_392_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): Have you done anything in your Rust version that you can already show? I would like to see how exactly it looks like. [...]
I post weekly updates about [my progress on ZeroMe](/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Profile/1MoonP8t4rk9QamBUPh5Aspkwa1Xhf5ux2/1CgdRv2BFaVqNfmK3qGVYDuA7EDmk8dJVS/anshorei@zeroid.bit), and also publish my branches to Git Center. It doesn't do much yet though:
- upnp
- local peer discovery
- content signing + verification
- serve ZN wrapper
- serve static files through wrapper
- establish websocket + a couple of API responses

I expect to have a (limited) working prototype somewhere in Q1, possibly in about a month (no promises though).
The focus of this prototype will be that the default zites (except Me which uses Merger) are browsable (i.e. look for peers, download/seed files, respond to FileGet, FileNeed, etc. requests). This means it may not be optimized. E.g. serving the wrapper does not use a template but an iterative string replace. Several async functions still block the thread.

> splitted implementation of the protocol itself and other code
That would be good, and it's also good practice in Rust (which strongly favours crates that do one thing and do it well, then combining those crates in the overarching project). The signing+verification is the only part I've put in a separate crate for now.

> Support for more network protocol features, like WebTorrent, DHT, PEX, HTTP seeding.
ZN already does PEX. DHT would be a great addition, and I've looked into it a bit but I think it's going to be one of the harder ones. I'd also like to add I2P and LokiNet in addition to Tor.

I don't have experience writing Rust bindings for C libraries, but it's supposed to be a well-documented use-case, I might try my hand at it, but it's definitely not a priority.

> Better (also non-iframe-based) wrapper/sandbox
I'm using the standard ZN wrapper (with 0 changes), the benefit of this is that if someone writes a better wrapper for ZeroNet it should be easy to replace in the Rust implementation as well.

Sadly ZeroNet is written in Python, and Python does not lend well to multithreading.

I've proposed (and am currently working on) an implementation of ZeroNet in Rust, a language that boasts several great advantages over Python such as overall performance (being low-level, no-GC, barely any overhead), memory safety guarantees and good multi-threading support. There is some disadvantages as well, eg. Plugins will not work and will need to either be integrated in the project, or into a fork. It's also still far from usable, and I'm kinda stuck right now...

> [vikingharvester](#comment_34_1FMwKKEcagXLLH4zWJf7BbKnFCL7eusmav): I hope you understood : forget centralized, not open sourced, not encrypted software... retroshare fits the perfectly your mission... https://retroshare.cc/

Retroshare is great, I'm using it with my family, but that said it's definitely still a WIP.
- Great control over reach: share with selected people or share with custom groups
- f2f (friend-to-friend) instead of p2p: Great for secure private communication, not good for global availability
- great filesharing (can limit to selected people): my family can easily download any the CD's I've ripped, my music friends have access to my sheet scans, all of my concert recordings and event photos are available to the other people who attended.
- ui feels very retro, responsive, not bloated
- great e-mail system (far better than ZeroMail)

The downsides:
- f2f instead of p2p leads to small reach, if you want to post publicly a p2p model like ZeroNet is better
- lack of features
- need to recompile to enable autologin (they disabled it for security purposes)
- ui feels very retro, not as slick as sites
- still quite a few small bugs

1587842259_17Y99cco6a5zgT4jbUXbh1ghnc9SP.body:
ZeroNet provides decentralization without anonymization.

Tor provides anonymization without decentralization.

By setting ZeroNet up in Tor-only mode (see the documentation) you get both anonymity and decentralization. On top of routing all traffic through Tor it also improves your privacy by creating new onion addresses for each site you connect an creating fresh ones every time you restart, this makes it harder to know when you're online and which sites you use (of course these can all be figured out by going through when/where you post with your ZeroID or other certificates).

To be clear: ZeroNet as a whole is NOT privacy-oriented. Some services like ZeroMail ARE privacy oriented. But most are 100% publicly available. ZeroNet is built for censorship resistance, decentralization and community-driven data longevity.

1588179678_1ErPX9yuZjokdcxUGavdRYRhwynA4.body: I'd like to seed, but some of the optional files appear to be missing. Could you check everything is signed and published and keep seeding until I have everything?

If they are optional files I don't really see a reason to remove the old content, I've got more than enough spare space for seeding.

**The problem is that I can't seem to get past the 5 minute mark for episode 14.** Other episodes that I've tried like 13 worked fine.

If the reason why you remove old episodes is because it takes longer to sign there's a solution for that:
```
+ Shows
    + Shows 11-20
        - content.json
        - Episode 11
        - Episode etc.
    + Shows 1-10
        - content.json
        - Episode 1
        - Episode 2
        - Episode etc.
```
You then need to add each of the subfolder's content.json's as includes to the main content.json
Then you no longer need to sign the files in the archives when you add new ones, only the one where you add the new one. This shouldn't really become a problem until you get to Episode 100 though.

> [ransbits](#comment_24_1H9xEgESUhfvpYK3SLLqabc1uLT2jsmH2A): nobody would be able to know what their community address is or what is being discussed. [...]

I don't think that's true, publishing on ZeroNet requires making the address known to trackers, so unless they use ECIES/AES to encrypt their posts, others could listen in on their "hidden" ZeroTalk clone.

The goal of ZeroNet is accessibility and transparency of data, and the only way around that is the ECIES/AES cryptography methods offered by the API e.g. ZeroMail. If you want secret fora I recommend trying RetroShare instead, that network is focused on privacy.

I'm not sure about 100's of times better. In the past I've ported a python application with a lot of calculations (3d manipulation and shape overlap) that did get into the 100's of times performance increase, but the slow speed in the original application was not just due to Python, it was mostly due to the use of slow libraries and lack of multi-threading. 1597255787_1NH142U7sEqKGnZXg5VUFp5SPtSjd.body:
How large are your galleries (number of images and filesize)? What browser are you using? What ZeroGallery hub did you clone? Which `content.json` is missing? `/galleries/content.json` or `/galleries/$GALLERYID$/content.json`?

I recommend using [GalleryHub+](/14NFfVBBAFbNdqX4nyGjyBF1BRSz7jn2QP) which has more features. I just tested it with a small gallery of five images and it worked fine.

Tor Browser disables a lot of optimizations by default that help speed up Javascript, the hub uses a JS implementation of ImageMagick to generate the thumbnails, this process is going to be considerably slower in the Tor Browser (but should still work as no canvases are used).

If your galleries are large or your computer is slow you may want to add the photos in separate batches e.g. 50, then another 50 (prepend is broken but append works).

If that's too tedious or slow you could also try [Rust0gal](/1KJquoRGNoC3sZWj56WEtSaLKg9hYupnX9), but it has no documentation, probably only works on linux and requires you to have imagemagick installed.

1598912261_1Au471PrXrTD9fdN8uQR4W93qMunb.body:
1. The only thing that is validated is ownership of data using bitcoin cryptography (i.e. did bitcoin address 1AddRESs sign this data? y/n)
2. No, there is no way to validate other nodes fairly generated random numbers etc.
3. You can get peer ips or onion addresses and you can do anything with them you can think of with js/wasm. You might also want to look into ZeroNet PeerMessage which can be used to deliver data to all or specific peers.

**What are good cases to use ZeroNet in a game?**
- Content signed by the developer. ZeroNet is good for content distribution because people downloading your game will also host it so you don't have to pay for hosting it.
- User-generated content hosting such as custom maps and mods. Any data that does not have to be validated anywhere other than client-side (ie. download map, check if it is a valid map). ZeroNet can continue distributing content long after you've stopped maintaining the game. Servers for old games go down, that is not a worry on ZeroNet.

**What are bad cases to use ZeroNet in a game?**
- Leaderboards, multiplayer with many players. Anything that works best with authorized servers verifying data.

If you want decentralized computation you will have to look into blockchain solutions, there's no reason you couldn't use a blockchain (e.g. ethereum) for the 'centralized' parts (i.e. timestamps, randomness, ownership of items etc.) and ZeroNet for content distribution.

> [stivencannor](#comment_2_1Au471PrXrTD9fdN8uQR4W93qMunb1v53S): thank you for the awesome answer.so, there is not any validation at ZeroTalk and i can send a new topic, before the ZeroTalk Creation. attention to the "new" topic word. im talking about new data with new address, not changing data. new data has new address and i am submitting invalid date Time. then i have new address and valid bit address. at this example. im not changing other people data.

1. By default, with the exception of the owner of a zite, no one can alter user-submitted data other than the user who submitted it. It is possible for the owner of a zite to add co-owners and theoretically this could be used to add a group of 'moderators' who can remove/alter data. However it's more in line with the philosophy of ZeroNet to have moderators maintain a blocklist without giving them the right to alter user data (for transparency and moderator accountability).
2. It is up to the zite developer to handle invalid data submitted by users either by omission or sanitizing. If invalid data submitted by users causes problems on the zite that should be considered a bug with the zite, not with ZeroNet. Most zites use ZeroNet's SQLite features, these can make it easy to ignore invalid data (string in json where integer is expected etc.).
3. There are multiple zites that include mining scripts, the more ethical of these ask you to allow mining before activating, others do not. It's up to us as users to spread blocklists of these sites and/or use browser plug-ins to block such scripts (just like on the normal web).
4. Don't execute files downloaded from untrusted sources, whether from the clearnet or ZeroNet. Spreading trojans through ZeroNet should be no different from normal web. Again it's up to us as users to create blocklists for sites and/or users that trick people into executing trojans.
5. I don't consider *hosting* trojans to be an issue personally, it would be an interesting idea to have a zite hosting a kind of trojan archive for people to dissect.
